Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Creating Novel Graphene-Based Metematerials through Nanopatterning
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This GOALI project aims to create a robust and reproducible bandgap in graphene. To achieve this goal, superlattices of various geometries are studied, tailoring the band structure, the effective mass, carrier group velocity and other electronic properties of the metamaterials. The project involves collaboration between academia (Purdue University) and industry (IBM T.J. Watson Research Center). One of the experimental approaches is to use a nano-patterning mask to create graphene superlattices with aggressively scaled lattice dimensions and true periodicities. Another approach involves utilizing an external potential with a superlattice periodicity imprinted onto graphene. A comparison of the electronic properties of periodically patterned graphene metamaterials and gated graphene enables an in-depth study of the impact of edge states on the band structures of the metamaterials. The success of this research project can provide a general solution to fabricating superlattices in two-dimensional materials by nano-scale patterning.

Non-technical Description: This research project addresses one of the most pressing challenges in the graphene field: how to create a robust and reproducible bandgap to enable practical uses of graphene in analog and digital electronics. Through a joint study between Purdue University and IBM, novel patterning methods are investigated in order to achieve the periodic and reproducible features required for bandgap creation. In addition, this project provides opportunities for the training of graduate and undergraduate students in materials science, nano-patterning, and device engineering. The PI is also committed to participate in and contribute to educational outreach programs at Purdue University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While graphene is a promising material due to its extraordinary properties, the lack of a bandgap has proven to be a major obstacle for many electronic applications. The main reason is that bandgap formation typically requires introducing quantization conditions by lithographical methods and etching which unavoidably introduces additional scattering sites and defects. The objective of this research is to address one of the most pressing challenges in the graphene research field – how to create a robust and reproducible band gap in graphene.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The funded project is a unique combination of material science, nano-patterning, and device engineering. Two main approaches have been employed to create the desired material properties in graphene. In the first approach, graphene is patterned into nanomesh structures with high periodicity. While the “charge puddle” phenomena has been found to be the dominant factor in carrier transport for most graphene devices and prevents access to the true “Dirac” point, the demonstrated nanomesh graphene structure in this project successfully bypasses these “puddles” and recovers excellent transport properties of graphene. Field-effect transistors (FETs) using these graphene nanomesh as channel materials show improved device characteristics and the same devices using nanomesh contacts are able to achieve high performance, low noise and high reliability. In the second approach, nano-patterning and design of the graphene FET gate stack allow a robust opening of large bandgaps in bilayer graphene. Through careful experimental demonstrations and analysis, a unique percolative transport model originated from the charge impurities embedded in the gate stack is proposed to understand the previously reported difficulties in opening large bandgaps in graphene. By scaling the gate oxide to 7nm and employing a 100nm BLG ribbon channel, a sizable bandgap of 200meV is observed which is almost 2 times larger than what was ever reported. With a large bandgap being opened in bilayer graphene, p/n junctions fabricated on electrostatically gated bilayer graphene show non-linear diode behaviors and unique resonant tunneling induced off-states are observed.

It is expected that the new graphene meta-materials with appreciable band gaps and desired transport properties will have a significant impact in the electronic and optoelectronic fields including digital and analog applications. Moreover, the approach of creating a periodic pattern has been applied to both, the graphene channel through etching and the gate stack through transferring a distinct electrostatic potential in order to compare the impact of these two orthogonal methods. The project has provided in depth experimental insights of the impact of edge states and trap charges in patterned or gated graphene structures. The ultimate applicability of the modified graphene meta-materials with bandgaps and better performance can be tested in various RF and logic devices and circuits, in terms of device/circuit performance and scalability.

 

Broader Impact:

 As pointed out above, many electronic applications, in particular various analog and digital circuits pursuit by the semiconductor industry require semiconducting properties of the channel material. Without this feat, even a material as graphene cannot be implemented and become useful for improved electronics applications. Most importantly, any bandgap formed needs to be created through a reproducible and reliable method that holds up to industry standards. Through a joined study between Purdue and IBM, two novel patterning methods have been employed to create reproducible features that are mandatory to accomplish the desired task. At the same time the proposed effort includes an integrated education and outreach program that aims at addressing critical challenges in current nano-materials and nano-devices related education. The program includes 1) the inclusion of nano-patterning of low dimensional materials into existing courses (e.g. ECE695 currently taught by PI), 2) the integration of undergraduate students into nano-related research programs by participation in the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF) program and hiring of undergraduates as summer interns, 3) active recruitment of minorities in the research program including female graduate and undergraduate students, 4) contributions to the annual Nano-days at the Birck Center with the emphasis on nano-patterning aspects, 5) Development of hands-on graphene demonstrations for grade 3-5 students.
